fields.customfield_10301:
I think you cannot overwrite the Model field easily, but you can reproduce the issue using a registry key instead.

Step 1: Create a test registry key of type string HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Tanium\Tanium Server\test
Step 2: Copy and paste the character in the attached text file as the string value
Step 3: Ask a question like "Get Computer Name and Registry Value Data[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Tanium\Tanium Server, test] from all machines". It might be easier if you open the file in Sublime as some text editors do not display the control code. If you've done it correctly you you should see a character that looks like the symbol for tau in the regedit field display.

Expected results: No data in the Interact Table

If you repeat the steps above with but with a valid ascii character and the table should render.

fields.description:
If the control code character for for SYN is included in the data payload of a response, all data fails to display in the Interact results table. JIRA won't let me paste in the character, so I've attached it in the file syn_character.txt.

This issue was found at a customer where the Model sensor returned the SYN character for a single machine. Data was returned to the browser, but the table failed to render. It also does not cause an issue with the excel plugin.

I suspect the character causes issues for our xml parser, as it returns a parsing error for frontend tools like http://codebeautify.org/xmlviewer.
fields.summary: Control Code SYN character prevents Interact Table from rendering

fields.customfield_10301:
Download GoToMyPC - this is the application that this was witnessed on; install on test Windows unit (was done on Win7 but should be the same regardless of Windows platform)
https://www.gotomypc.com/downloads/manual/1875/gosetup.exe

Look at Control Panel / Programs and verify you can see GoToMyPC installed

Run Installed Applications sensor and filter for GoTo - verify it is not reported

Traverse to HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall\{73125252-5733-403D-92B1-20BB091E2F8E} and verify no UninstallString is present

Add a new value - REG_EXPAND_SZ with bogus data in it - anything will do

Rerun Installed Applications and verify it is now reporting GoToMyPC

Jamie Moyer located the code that seems to be causing this:


line 62 in script.. 
If displayName <> "" _
          And Not IsNull(uninstallString) _
fields.description:
Not sure if this is the right category or not but Installed Applications sensor is not returning results on Windows for applications which do not have an UninstallString even though the application is reported by Control Panel.

If a bogus UninstallString is added to the program's HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall\GUID key then Installed Applications reports it correctly.

See discussion on #content channel on this for more info: https://tanium.slack.com/archives/content/p1472748753000047
fields.summary: Installed Applications sensor does not return data if UninstallString is missing

root@PlexServer:/etc/init.d# ./taniumclient start

   Loaded: loaded (/etc/init.d/taniumclient; bad; vendor preset: enabled)
   Active: failed (Result: exit-code) since Tue 2016-10-04 12:21:55 EDT; 5s ago
     Docs: man:systemd-sysv-generator(8)
  Process: 5554 ExecStart=/etc/init.d/taniumclient start (code=exited, status=1/FAILURE)

Oct 04 12:21:55 PlexServer systemd[1]: Starting LSB: Tanium Client...

fields.description:
*** Please note *** I am aware we don't officially support 16.04 but I found this issue and wanted to report it to hopefully save someone troubleshooting time in the future. 

The taniumclient init.d script is converting the $prog variable to lowercase and because the client executable is upper case (TaniumClient) the service fails to start.

The $prog variable is set properly to TaniumClient on line 14 of the startup script but you can see in the error it is converted to lower case (taniumclient).

DISTRIB_ID=Ubuntu
DISTRIB_RELEASE=16.04
DISTRIB_CODENAME=xenial
DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS"

fields.description:
h1. Summary
Sensor titled "Windows Credential Security Settings"

The objective of this sensor would be to collect settings related to Windows account and authentication security, inclusive of mitigations for pass-the-hash and mimikatz and new features introduced in Windows 8 and later.

This sensor should only evaluate settings that are configured on individual endpoints. Settings related to domain accounts or to the Active Directory domain configuration itself should not be included. 

h1. Settings to Check

An initial list of checks that should be included in the first version of this sensor are included below.

h2. KB2871997 Enhanced Credential Security and Pass-the-Hash Mitigation
This update applies to Windows 7, Server 2008 R2 and later. It implements a number of mechanisms to mitigate credential theft and re-use techniques made popular by tools such as Mimikatz.

Sensor should simply check if this patch is installed.

h2. WDigest Provider Status
Determine if the WDigest authentication provider is enabled. Mimikatz can recover clear-text credentials in-memory from this provider for current and recently authenticated users. WDigest may be necessary for certain applications. On Windows 8.1/Windows 2012 R2, this value is set to 0 (Digest disabled). The default value is "1" for earlier versions of Windows for backwards compatibility

Sensor should evaluate the following registry key, and return "Disabled" or "Enabled":
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\WDigest
Value: UseLogonCredential
Data: 1 if enabled, 0 if disabled

h2. LSA Protection Status
Determines if LSASS is configured as a Protected Process Light (only available Windows 8.1 / Server 2012 R2 and later).

Sensor should output "N/A" for non-applicable operating systems. For applicable operating systems, check:

Key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa
Value: RunAsPPL
Data: dword 00000001 if enabled

h2. LSA Auditing
Configures whether Code Integrity Event Logging will record violations of LSA Protected Process settings. Only applicable to Windows 8.1 / Server 2012 R2 and later when LSA is configured as a PPL.

Key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\LSASS.EXE
Value: AuditLevel
Data: dword 00000008 if enabled

h2. Restricted Admin Mode
Determines when Restricted Administration mode is enabled for remote clients connecting to this system. This setting is only available to Windows 7 and Server 2008 R2 and later. All other operating systems should return an "N/A" for the check.

Key: HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa
Value: DisableRestrictedAdmin
Data: dword 0 means Restricted Admin *is enabled*

h2. Restricted Admin Outbound Credentials
Determines whether the machine account credentials will be used for outbound connections. This setting is only available to Windows 7 and Server 2008 R2 and later. All other operating systems should return an "N/A" for the check.

Key: HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa
Value: DisableRestrictedAdminOutboundCreds
Data: dword 1 means machine account credentials will not be used for outbound connections from this system

h2. Cached Domain Logon Credentials
Setting that determines how many domain account credentials will be cached for logon if the domain controller is not reachable.

Key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\Current Version\Winlogon 
Value: CachedLogonsCount
Data: REG_SZ set to range 0 - 50

h2. UAC Enabled
Controls whether User Access Control (UAC) is enabled and will prompt the user when programs attempt to gain elevated privileges to modify the system.

Key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\policies\system
Value: EnableLUA
Data: dword of 0 to disable, 1 to enable

h2. Local Account Token Filter Policy
Controls whether UAC privileges permit Administration elevation for local accounts. This setting only applies to Vista SP2 and later and Server 2008 and later. All other operating systems should return an "N/A" for the check.

Key:HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System
Value: LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy
Data: dword 0 or 1
0	This value builds a filtered token. This is the default value. The administrator credentials are removed.
1	This value builds an elevated token

h2. LM Hash Status
Key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\policies\system\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa
Value: NoLMHash
Data: dword of 1 to disable storage of the LM hash (following a password reset)


h1. Sensor Input Parameters
N/A

h1. Output Format
One row of output per setting evaluated on the endpoint. There should be three output columns: Setting name, setting value (use "friendly" term like disabled / enabled vs. raw data, Operating System
fields.summary: New Sensor: Windows Credential Security Settings

fields.description:
For a plugin like below, I am thinking of the attribute skip_to_on_exit_code="4|2,5|3", which means that on exit code 4, the execution will skip to command seq#2, and likewise on exit code 5, it will skip to command seq#3.

<commands>
	<command seq="1" postback="true" abort_exit_code="0" skip_to_on_exit_code="4|2,5|3">cmd /c cscript /Nologo SyncFilesManager.wsf</command>	
	<command seq="2" postback="false" abort_exit_code="0">cmd /c cscript /Nologo UpdateManifestPackage.wsf</command>
	<command seq="3" postback="false" abort_exit_code="0">cmd /c cscript /Nologo ReissueDistManifestAction.wsf</command>
</commands>

This will allow the plugin authors to have greater control on what get executed or not. For my use case, I need to look up the target package/action IDs if they are not ready yet, and I can probably skip the lookup with this feature.
fields.summary: SOAP API for plugin with multiple commands: conditional skipTo commands in the sequence

fields.description:
We have an issue where calling sys.exit() will cause a sensor to exit, but will not keep tanium.result and print. Instead, it throws an exception which the sensor catches.

sensor code:

tanium.result = 'foo'
sys.exit()


TSE-Error: class RunScriptException:Unexpected error.

We have to come up with some way to halt execution of a sensor, without using regular control flow methods, so that 

A) Customers don't have to construct the code in a special way
B) It's easy to do and remember (tanium.exit?)

The main issue is that python sensors will not be timed out by the client, and we are working on a way to time them out by simply importing tanium.
fields.summary: sys.exit() will not halt Internal python sensor gracefully

fields.description:
With Jenkins 2.X -- the "includes" are downloaded straight from the external test manifest.

This is better long term -- it means tighter control over what version of a content pack another content pack builds against.  

But it requires a new value in the tanium.properties, so that the source code is included in what is pushed as part of the distribution:

content.solution.include.src.enabled=1

This property will mean that the source is included when its pushed, and then other projects can depend on it, and include it (and it will be downloaded automatically)
fields.summary: Enable src build / distribution for dependency downloads

Gerald Henson [8:58 AM]  
in the next version of connect, you can indicate either a json per line (per record) or a true json object

<snip>

we have customers that need both

Matt Machczynski [8:59 AM]

that is another new feature, the ability to add columns to the output. right now there are 2 different column types you can add, one is timestamp, where you have control over the format and the column name, and the other is just a hard-coded value, where you control the column name and just a hard-coded value

To get tanium to run I had to manually create a symbolic link from /opt/Tanium/TaniumClient/TaniumClient to /opt/Tanium/TaniumClient/taniumclient and that seemed to do the trick.

fields.description:
This is an attempt to limit the effects of things like the Xerox bug, or the Sev 1 Citi incident.

Through some iterations of different options, the one decided on was:

-  If the client attempts to run a sensor, and it fails (for length of time, for code errors, for... etc) then start recording the failure counts
- Develop an algorithm to stop running the sensor.  Do not blindly keep executing it -- do something smarter.  (to be determined)
- If the sensor is not being run because its reached the failure conditions, return a string as the response that indicates as such.  TSE-Sensor Busted

This should help considerably with the problem sensors spinning out of control, and causing process build up on machines -- the ill effects should be much more limited.
fields.summary: If a Sensor execution fails, limit future executions

fields.description:
Currently TDownloader on windows instead of openssl. This is nice because it is FIPS compliant, simplifies the build, uses the windows certificate store, etc. However, it is bad because it is a black box out of our control. 

One example of an issue that schannel has made very difficult for us is [SERVER-2247] -- we cannot set its proxy settings for when it reaches out to the internet to do a CRL check. It also introduces a difference in what code is running on windows/linux, which is somewhat minor, but perhaps not ideal. 

TDownloader's curl should be built against openssl, not winssl (or at least controlled with a flag if it is possible to have both). I think we should keep it using the windows certificate store programmatically or else bring back UpdateCACert to export the windows cert store.
fields.summary: TDownloader should use OpenSSL instead of schannel

fields.description:
While working on the raw proxy plugin I discovered, and Ben confirmed, that the current implementation of the server plugin doesn’t support Chunked Transfer Encoding for plug-ins.  I discovered this by testing the proxy plugin against several well known websites, as an attempt to find glaring holes in my plugin implemntation .  The site that exposed the lack of chunking support was google’s home page, www.google.com. As Ben articulated, there are several known work arounds to using transfer encoding, (1) Use Content-Length on the request/response that would other wise use chunked encoding (2) Use HTTP 1.0 instead HTTP 1.1.  

The overarching concern is that we can’t ensure that the workarounds are provided in every scenario.  In some cases we don’t control the full response, e.g. if a customer or partner uses our product APIs with a scripting language or third part utility e.g. wget/cURL.  Even in the cases we are, Tanium, are writing the code we don’t usually have full control of the HTTP request. For example, chunked encoding is the default for Node.js

There are already a couple known examples in our products where chunking maybe invoked by either the client or the server.  Here are two concrete flows: (1) IOCFunnel: Multiple IOC upload (2) System Monitor: DB upload (3) System Monitor: File Get from endpoint
fields.summary: Chunked Encoding not supported by Server Plugin

fields.description:
This has been observed in 2.1.0004 and earlier builds of the Client Service Hardening solution.

When deploying the _Client Service Hardening - Allow Only Local SYSTEM to Control Service_ package, it effectively breaks the ability to fully uninstall the client because the SYSTEM account doesn't have sufficient permissions to delete the Tanium Client service. The residual service causes problems when reinstalling the client, in that the service doesn't automatically start upon installation. In addition, the installer never truly finishes, and the process tree below stays alive indefinitely:
* InstallTanium.exe
    * cmd.exe
        * SetupClient.exe

The system which launched the installation of the Tanium Client would therefore either timeout, or just never return a success code. 

As observed in CONTENT-785, this issue also affects upgrades.
fields.summary: Allow Only Local SYSTEM to Control Service breaks the uninstaller

fields.description:
Diane Bowers (Citi):

One of the critical items found during our VA testing is the storage of the key file (soapserver.key and installed-server.key) unencrypted. This is a formal request to code the application to be able to input the key password during configuration so the file can be stored encrypted. Similar vendors provide this functionality. For instance, McAfee allows this to be configured within the ePO console. I am not aware where this is stored, likely in the database.

John Pao (Citi):

These 2 are definitely going to lead to a high risk finding -
 
·         Sensitive Info stored in clear text - SOAPServer.key

·         Lack of user access controls - SOAPServer.key

 
ACLs aren’t good enough.  Our standards state –
 
Symmetric and private keys are either stored in a hardware cryptographic module (HSM), or encrypted and stored in a key store file protected with a passphrase with minimum length of 8 alphanumeric characters.
 
I know it becomes a bit of the same issue encrypting the private key because it needs to be unencrypted to make it usable.  However, you guys need to build another layer of control over the stored key.
fields.summary: Request to enhance Tanium Server to allow reading encrypted key file

fields.description:
This is a bug that is blocking something in Trace. But truly this has far 
reaching goodness potential, and it's time to do it I think.

We want to be able to have the Trace Web app control the number of lines the 
Trace sensors can return, which is defined in the sensor code. One (rather 
silly) option is have the trace webapp rewrite the sensor code each time a 
preference is set in the Trace UI. But I'd like to have this be a much more 
widely used thing, as that would be a waste of work, and it's a huge problem 
for us in general.

Currently, the limitation of lines that Trace can return in an org-wide sensor 
is done in sensor code with a MaxOutputLines property of the TaniumTraceQuery 
Object in the vbscript. so you'll see a line that looks like this:

x.MaxOutputLines = 150

What I would prefer is an extensible system where the data that would be 
substituted in would be a global setting, and the results of that global 
setting can be the sensor parameter data.

So rather than accept a type-in parameter, we would need a new type of 
parameter - a setting name, whose data gets inserted into the sensor. The 
setting name could be something like

preference_sensor_<name>_key

So for the Trace Executed Processes sensor, which has ||MaxLines|| in the 
script code, would have a parameter whose type is Global Preference, and would 
read in the *text* of the value
preference_sensor_Trace_Executed_Processes_MaxLines

which is a type:Text, affects: Server global setting.
It would be entered into the database safely - escaped and all that.


The very same system (code shared) for Package parameters - 

preference_package_Blahby_Blah_$1

We would need to handle default values, and that would mean a second set of 
global settings which would be included in the Content xml, and would need to 
be importable. So it may be that content needs to define these as new XML 
nodes, or defined in the metadata keypair node, and the importer needs to 
examine these keys and write global settings on import. These would take the 
form:

preference_default_package_<name>_<key>

If a product or customer overrode the global settings with a non-default value, 
it would take that value. Otherwise, it would insert the default value.

Open to alternative approaches for sure, this is very back of the napkin, but 
this is the gist of what I would like to see done - however you can do it. This 
bug is all about creating something that will eliminate, over time, the really 
really horrible system where we hardcode stuff in packages and sensors, and 
then it gets stomped when stuff is imported.

I can't think of a better way to do this than to abuse the current global 
settings system. I'd classify solving this one as high priority, and is 1/2 of 
CONSOLE-775 antoher terribly high priority bug.
fields.summary: A proposal for getting rid of hardcoded data in sensors and actions

fields.description:
A guy at BGC deployed something and said he had no way to validate that it got there successfully.  It did not get there, and he found out because the end user called him.  Of course he could have written a question to find out, and that's what I told him.  But ...


Is there any way we could find some way to echo something back in our code that would indicate to the tanium client that the action has, in fact, failed to execute properly instead of failed to execute at all, which is what we have today?

If the action results caught by the client and logged, we could turn failure reporting into a very easy exercise, right?  Now if the vbs executes and fails, instead of showing success on all machines, the action author could control the conditions under which it would show failure.  And why, too.

Some kind of phrase like 'tanium error: <and then in vbscript something like err.description>

And for all other cases, when it can't echo and the program returns an error code back to the OS, can we catch that?

SCCM will show errors for advertised programs, but it totally sucks.  Good luck finding it at all, and good luck getting it in a timely manner.  

I don't believe bigfix will return any text or error code from the executed command line, but I might be wrong - my memory is getting fuzzier.

Aside from being tremendously valuable to administrators, if we can do this, and if we can implement chaining actions together, we can implement logical chains inside an action group - do this and do this, but only if the first thing actually worked.  SCCM has this capability.  Chaining is bug http://bugs.tanium.com/show_bug.cgi?id=704

fields.description:
Sensor Inputs: 
	• Account Search String
	• Host search string
	• Max returned per host (1-30)

Sensor Output Columns:
	• Local Profile
	• RDP Target Name or IP
	• Remote Logon Account

This sensor code reads each user profile registry hive under HKU. Each profile has an entry matching the SID of the account. This sensor uses the ProfileList in the registry to translate the SID into the account name and displays that in the first column in the output, labled "Local Profile". Whenever the Remote Desktop Connection client (mstsc.exe) is used to establish a connection to another computer, there is an entry stored in the User hive of the registry. Column two contains the hostname or IP address of the system in which the connection was made and is labled "RDP Target Name or IP". The account used to login to the target system is shown in the third column.

Since this sensor has the potential for returning an overwhelming number of rows of data in large environments, the sensor has a selector pull-down where the maximum number of entries can be chosen. It is best to start conservative and see how many rows of output comes back. The choices are 1,2,5,10,15,20 and 30 rows per endpoint. Typically the TSC utility only stores the last 10 connections, but because on shared computers there can be multiple profiles, the maximum is used to control the number of per-host rows. 

To further control the amount of data sent back, there are two string filters and one of them must be used. If no value is provided for one of the filters, an error message will state that "Error: Must supply either username or server search string". The first filter for "accounts" will search against strings in the first and third columns, while the "host" filter searches the second column. Using both of these is helpful in examining specific account usage across the environment.

Start by examining high level privilege accounts. For example, AD administrators, service accounts, database administrators, etc. should all be monitored closely. If you see the profile for one user accessing and logging in with an account they shouldn't be using, it would be important to understand that activity. Use the drill-down to get computer name and other details related to questionable activity.

fields.description:
If you get the "Access denied : Error code : -2147024891" error, it is probably an issue with access rights / privileges. Please check the following points on the remote computer :
If the remote host runs Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, or Windows 7 and that UAC is enabled, WMI requests sent throught network can not be executed with elevated administration privileges.
You can disable the User Account Control or disable UAC only for remote access (recommended).  Open the registry base with "regedit", then open "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\system". Create (if it does not exist) the following DWORD value : LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy and set it to 1. To enable again UAC for remote access, just delete this value or set it to 0.
- If the remote host is in the same domain as yours, our software must be launched with administrative rights (you should be a member of the "Administrators"/"Domain Admins" group).
- If the remote host is in another domain, then the user account and the password used on your administrative computer (the one where our software is installed), must identically exist on the remote computer, and be a member of the local "Administrators" group.

fields.description:
We use TerminateThread to stop long running internal vbscript execution. But TerminateThread is documented to say that you should never call it:

{quote}TerminateThread is a dangerous function that should only be used in the most extreme cases. You should call TerminateThread only if you know exactly what the target thread is doing, and you control all of the code that the target thread could possibly be running at the time of the termination.

For example, TerminateThread can result in the following problems:

* If the target thread owns a critical section, the critical section will not be released.
* If the target thread is allocating memory from the heap, the heap lock will not be released.
* If the target thread is executing certain kernel32 calls when it is terminated, the kernel32 state for the thread's process could be inconsistent.
* If the target thread is manipulating the global state of a shared DLL, the state of the DLL could be destroyed, affecting other users of the DLL.{quote}

From talking to [~dan.hardy@tanium.com], it sounds like this is only used as a last resort. I think that makes it much lower priority, but we should still stop using it.
fields.summary: Stop using TerminateThread

fields.description:
Requesting a new client and server feature where you can mark a sensor, and perhaps by setting a value in the sensor code, maybe a tanium.method or property, that would indicate that I am about to send string data but i do not want you to remember and store this string data

My best example is a saved question that exports trace data, along with ephemeral ports, to antoher system so they can marry host and network data by matching connections. This, today, would kill client RAM, server RAM, essentially unbounded, and would impact bandwidth in a bounded way.

I asked Ryan Kazanciyan for any further use cases, but we both agree that there are so many arbitrary use case examples:

"Any circumstance where we are collecting non-stackable data. Lots of examples in Trace and IR sensors as you said. Especially when drill-down is not an option - i.e. For recurring saved questions pumped to a SIEM"

We really very badly need this feature. It must be controllable in the sensor code. For instance, if the sensor detects a particular parameter, it would set tanium.dontkeepstrings = True and control the client behavior at run time.

External execution is tough in this way, but tough. let's move away from it over time.

If this is set, a special preamble string is sent to the server and the server knows to never store the answer set, or only store it for the amount of time that it would be technically necessary to store it for functionality purposes, or would at least know to clean it at some configurable period.

The client would know to keep the strings for only as long as the sensor's max age value inside the specific question.

We really need to be able to do something like this. Changes/challenges to the idea accepted, but this is holding us back in real ways, and it's the one thing that keeps us from being able to do what other products in our space can do.

Thought about it for years, and have filed similar nebulous bugs such as 'hey peter, there are going to be a lot of strings emitted from trace, what can we do?'

I doubt there's anyone on the IR team that doesn't think this is very important and a huge step we can take, so I'm marking it major and assigning it to mealins, which is as close as I dare to go to assigning it to Orion :) Reclassify as necessary.
fields.summary: Content controllable flag to tell client, and server, to not remember these strings

fields.description:
Jesse, please mark this as a 6.5 must fix for release, so we don't forget it:

The content build system has been producing content packs that are signed by the content.pvk / content.pub that is currently installed with the 6.5 server install.

Its been doing this for a few months now, so all existing "old" content packs have this signature on them.

This is great for this phase of testing, but I think we should swap out new keys before the product actually ships.

We can count the current key in the signing keys as a test key -- but I think we should put more controls around the "official" content before 6.5 ships.

The older content that is already signed doesn't really matter -- the 6.2 didn't check signatures anyway.  So I don't think taking this step before release would be bad - some customers might not be able to install their current code, but there is even old code they wouldn't be able to install anyway.

The Manifest key is safe -- it has never been part of the standard build process, and has taking manual steps to sign any manifest at the official install location.

Still need to work out what the process would be to have content officially signed, but I've decided I don't like it being auto signed by the build process whenever pushed out, would be better to put some other kind of process in place.

Suggestions welcome for what that process should be.
fields.summary: Replace current content.pub and plugin keys before 6.5 release

fields.description:
GE previously upgraded from 6.5.314.4380 to 6.5.314.4410 approximately 20 days ago. The initially had the secondary server crash 9 days after the upgrade. These current crashes occurred 10 days after the first crash. Uploaded TaniumServer Logs Log0 and Log1 which had to be split into 10MB chunks due to file size upload restriction.

Server 01 crashed at 10:45PM on 10/17/16
Server 02 crashed at 11:25PM on 10/17/16

Stack trace was captured remotely from the dump files which were 175GB and 215GB in size.

Tanium Server Crash: Version (4410)
Random Occurrence
Not able to reproduce
Crash generates +200GB DMP file (unable to send to MoveIt).
Following commands executed on customer environment:
* !analyze -v
* !uniqstack

All Files with output attached to JIRA.

fields.description:
Tanium Client crashes after increasing to over 2GB of RAM usage.
We don't understand how the Tanium Client could get to 2GB RAM usage, but also don't understand why the process is crashing at 2GB RAM usage.

Its difficult to get to teh 2GB RAM usage, so the issue is not easily reproducible.

fields.description:
Based on good info that Paul found, we should begin creating more comprehensive 'firewall status' sensors.

These sensors should cover 

Firewall Installed
Firewall Active
Firewall Rules Applied (by name or worst case ID)
Rule description (with name / ID as input)

Anything else we think we could do that would translate to any firewall technology.

For any sensor, it would identify the technology / provider in the first column.

Downsides to applying the same sensors to all technologies:
1) Code could get larger than the sensor character limit (Sensor theoretical max 32K in size). Would need to write as tightly as possible.
2) Square peg in round hole syndrome

Upsides:
1) would make it very easy to identify all the firewall types on the network by asking a single sensor
2) an attempt to normalize the data
3) single dashboard for diagnostics / troubleshooting question performance


Assigning to Paul to see if he could comment on whether this one size fits all approach would work for Symantec. Rory can investigate McAfee HIPS. Windows Firewall looks doable http://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/scriptcenter/Script-to-display-the-b4e61729, can pull names and rule definitions out of the registry.


------------
Paul sent data to Jim Resch on general registry, but doesn't seem to show Firewall Rules

1. To check the Version of currently installed SEP client

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\SMC

ProductVersion  

Value will be something like 11.0.4014.26

 
2. Client is communicating with SEPM or is OFFLINE

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\SMC\SYLINK\SyLink

PolicyMode  1 – means communicating 0- means offline.

3. Which Group the client is pointing to

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\SMC\SYLINK\SyLink

Preferredgroup

4. Policy Serial Number on Client

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\SMC\SYLINK\SyLink

SerialNumber

Value will be something like 2DD9-09/09/2009 00:05:14 125

5. To know the Hardware ID for the Client

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\SMC\SYLINK\SyLink

HardwareID

6. What is the version of Virus Defintion the client is currently using .

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\SharedDefs

DEFWATCH_10

The value will be some like C:\PROGRA~1\COMMON~1\SYMANT~1\VIRUSD~1\20090907.050

7. To know what IPS Signature SEP is using

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\SharedDefs\SymcData-cndcipsdefs

cndcIps

The value will be like: C:\PROGRA~1\COMMON~1\SYMANT~1\SymcData\CNDCIP~1\20090826.002

8. To check if Network Threat Protection is installed and is Turned ON.

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\SMC

smc_engine_status  0 – means turned OFF 1- turned ON.

9. Exclusion –Centralized Exceptions

32 bit

i. Security Risk Exceptions

User Defined Exceptions

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Exclusions\ClientRiskExceptions

Lock – 0- means the client can create Centralized Exceptions for Known Security Risks 1 – means this optioned is locked by the administrator in SEPM.

And Under the ClientRiskExceptions\1234567890 (normally a 10 digit numerical folder )  you will find the Known Security Risk exceptions created by the users.

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Exclusions\AdminRiskExceptions

Under the AdminRiskExceptions\1234567890 (normally a 10 digit numerical folder )  you will find the Known Security Risk exceptions created by the Admin from SEPM.

 

ii. Proactive Threat Protection Exclusions

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Exclusions\HeuristicScanning\FileHash

\Client\ 0728bd2bb1774b9728f60d33bc1f95172374e950–(The long hexadecimal numbers point to the filehash for the excluded file )  For the exclusions created by the user

\Admin\ 0728bd2bb1774b9728f60d33bc1f95172374e950 - (The long hexadecimal numbers point to the filehash for the excluded file ) -  For exclusions made by Admin from SEPM.

Same with Directory , Files and Folder Exclusions

iii. Directory

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Exclusions\ScanningEngines\Directory

\Admin  and \Client

iv. Files

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Exclusions\ScanningEngines\FileName

\Admin  and \Client

 
v.Extensions

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Exclusions\ScanningEngines\Extensions\

\Admin  and \Client

vi. Symantec also excludes it own Embedded Database from Scanning

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Exclusions\Symantec Embedded Database\FileExceptions

Out.log, Sem5.log and Sem5.db are excluded.

vii. To Verify Exchange Server exclusions on 32 Bit System

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Exclusions\Exchange Server

\FileExceptions and \NoScanDir

On 64 Bit system

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Exclusions

\FileExceptions and \NoScanDir

  

10. Now say you have remote laptops you exported a Default client install package and sent them.

Now you want to change them to Unmanaged.

You replaced sylink.xml for Unmanaged SEP Cd1\SEP\Sylink.xml

Still clients are not able to do the liveupdate and the default admin defined Scan runs.

Here is the default Admin Defined Scanand if you have created few more scans for this users it will also be listed in the same location but with a different name.

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\LocalScans\5df13630-79f7-4c70-002b-16b8952f5533 ( name can be any hexadecimal name )

So you can delete this and then you can create your own scan.

Liveupdate button is greyed out even after replacing sylink.

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\LiveUpdate

AllowManualLiveUpdate  0- means liveupdate button will be greyed out. 1-means it will be available to click.

In the same place you can enable product updates by changing the value of

EnableProductUpdates  to 1

For Scheduling and Enabling automatic liveupdates.

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\LiveUpdate\Schedule

Change the value of

Enabled to 1 – for Automatic updates.

11. Handling Quarantine

Sometimes due to infection the size of the quarantine folder grows huge.

It is not accessible via the GUI.So to know where and to change settings for Quarantine for the client

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Symantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\AV\Quarantine

Important keys

QuarantinePurgeBySizeEnabled set it to 1 –To enable Sizing of quarantine folder then

QuarantinePurgeBySizeDirLimit   Default value is 50 ( Megabytes)  either leave it at 50 or reduce it as much you want.

You can also lower the age of purging Quarantine items from default 30 days to any number of days you want

QuarantinePurgeAgeLimit   30 days by default.

12. How to disable Application and Device Control via registry

 

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\SysPlant

Change the Value of Start to 4 . 1 –means enabled.

13. Check this discussion on Creating Scan via registry 
https://www-secure.symantec.com/connect/forums/way-create-scan-registry

14. For Logging options via registry
How to debug the Symantec Endpoint Protection 11.x client
http://service1.symantec.com/SUPPORT/ent-security.nsf/docid/2007090611252048

 15. GUP information via registry
Troubleshooting the Group Update Provider (GUP) in Symantec Endpoint Protection
http://service1.symantec.com/SUPPORT/ent-security.nsf/docid/2008040113243148

16. Enable debugging of Auto Location switching (ALS) and this Reg key

HKLM\SOFTWARE\S ymantec\Symantec Endpoint Protection\SMC\Trident\AutoLocationDump

fields.description:
Hey, guys, a year later and I'm still running into issues at Allegiant Air with their license counts, so I wanted to confirm the recommended process to verify Tanium license compliance based on the API changes that have taken place since we discussed this in July of 2014 so I can determine if Allegiant needs to buy more licenses.

Earlier in the message stream below, Jesse mentioned a bug at https://bugs.tanium.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1751, but I'm not sure that's relevant anymore, so I'm going to start a new entry in JIRA

Allegiant Air is seeing the warning that they are over their license count:
"License count exceeded.  You currently have 2,024 clients and 2,000 licensed seats."  

They believe they have about 1,500 computers; however, to suppress the license non-compliance warning message resulting from the bug identified in the email correspondence below,  we gave them a license for 2000.  I believe that bug was closed, yet the warning message is appearing in the console again.  I'm trying to figure out how we're determining license usage today so I can resolve this discrepancy with Allegiant.

From the results in their server's /info page, I see the following values:  
"Estimated Node Count" : 1466  
"License Seat Cap" : 2220  

I've attached the full json file.

What other values should I be looking at to determine license compliance within the last 24 hour or the last 30 days?  

Thank you!

-----Original Message-----
From: Jesse Ward-Karet [mailto:jwk@tanium.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, July 30, 2014 4:05 PM
To: Peter Lincroft <peter@ansiblesoftware.com
Cc: Ben Hobbs <ben.hobbs@tanium.com; Kevin Chu <kevin.chu@tanium.com; Jim Resch <jim.resch@tanium.com; Peter Lincroft <Peter.Lincroft@tanium.com
Subject: Re: Allegiant Air | Questions related to License Count

Yes. The console uses whatever number is returned the the client_count API call, so we should update as described in #2.

On Jul 30, 2014, at 4:02 PM, Peter Lincroft <peter@ansiblesoftware.com wrote:

  I think that is the api that does the counting wrong. :)  It should be filtering out the clients with version 0.0.0.0, but it isn't.
 
 Jesse, is that the api the console is using?
 
 Its a bit confusing because the standards we use for counting the number of clients vary:
# estimated node count:  this is an estimate of the total number of clients currently online.  It includes 0.0.0.0 clients, but is limited to clients whose last registration time is less than max_registration_age, and whose protocol version exactly matches the server's protocol version.  When the license seat count is ENFORCED, this is the count that is used.
# deployed client count:  This is supposed to be the number of endpoints that have the client installed.  Traditionally we have counted this by counting all clients that have registered in the last 30 days, NOT INCLUDING the ones that have a 0.0.0.0 version.  This is (I think) the number we want to use to control whether the console pops up a "nag" message about being over your licensed limit.
 
 I hope I got that right. :)
 
 Thanks!
 
  --Peter Lincroft
 
 From: Ben Hobbs <ben.hobbs@tanium.com
 To: Peter Lincroft <peter@ansiblesoftware.com
 Cc: Kevin Chu <kevin.chu@tanium.com; Jim Resch 
 <jim.resch@tanium.com; Peter Lincroft <Peter.Lincroft@tanium.com; 
 Jesse Ward-Karet <jwk@tanium.com
 Sent: Wednesday, July 30, 2014 3:49 PM
 Subject: Re: Allegiant Air | Questions related to License Count
 
 Why don’t you use the SOAP request: GetObject-client_count?  It’s faster and more accurate that just counting entries in the system status request.
 
       <urn:tanium_soap_request
          <session</session
          <commandGetObject</command
          <object_list
 		
 	
 <client_count</client_count
          </object_list
       </urn:tanium_soap_request
 
 
 
 On Jul 30, 2014, at 3:46 PM, Peter Lincroft <peter@ansiblesoftware.com wrote:
 
  Yeah that would probably work.  SystemStatus.txt is the file.  Format is fairly simple, number of entries at start, then one line per entry after that... you could write a script to filter out the "0.0.0.0" lines and set the number of entries at the start to the correct value and that should work.  But it will be wrong again pretty quickly, so you would need to run the script fairly frequently.
  
 Thanks!
  
 --Peter Lincroft
 
 From: Kevin Chu <kevin.chu@tanium.com
 To: Peter Lincroft <peter@ansiblesoftware.com
 Cc: Jim Resch <jim.resch@tanium.com; Peter Lincroft 
 <Peter.Lincroft@tanium.com; Ben Hobbs <ben.hobbs@tanium.com; Jesse 
 Ward-Karet <jwk@tanium.com
 Sent: Wednesday, July 30, 2014 3:23 PM
 Subject: Re: Allegiant Air | Questions related to License Count
 
 Peter is it serialized that information I disk upon shutdown?  Would there be a safe way to clean that?
 
 Sent from my iPhone
 
  On Jul 30, 2014, at 2:30 PM, Peter Lincroft <peter@ansiblesoftware.com wrote:
  
 No, the table has been dropped from the database so there is no query possible.  I was referring to code that might have been messed up.  It sounds like the SOAP api is not filtering out the 0.0.0.0 clients way we want it to.
  
 Thanks!
  
 --Peter Lincroft
 
 From: Jim Resch <jim.resch@tanium.com
 To: peter@ansiblesoftware.com; Peter Lincroft 
 <Peter.Lincroft@tanium.com
 Cc: Kevin Chu <kevin.chu@tanium.com; Ben Hobbs 
 <ben.hobbs@tanium.com; Jesse Ward-Karet <jwk@tanium.com
 Sent: Wednesday, July 30, 2014 7:54 AM
 Subject: RE: Allegiant Air | Questions related to License Count
 
 Hi, Peter,
  
 Based on your comment, I was wondering if there is a database query we could run to clean up the entries that “may have gotten messed up when we made the changes to remove the network config table from the database”
  
 Thank you!
  
 Best regards,
  
 Jim Resch
 Technical Account Manager
  
 Jim.Resch@Tanium.com | +1 (510) 919-8828
  
 Support:  http://www.tanium.com/resources/
  
 
 
 From: Peter Lincroft [mailto:peter@ansiblesoftware.com]
 Sent: Monday, July 28, 2014 12:05 PM
 To: Jesse Ward-Karet; Jim Resch
 Cc: Kevin Chu; Ben Hobbs
 Subject: Re: Allegiant Air | Questions related to License Count
  
 The computers with 0.0.0.0 should not be counted when calculating 
 client count... this may have gotten messed up when we made the 
 changes to remove the network config table from the database Sent 
 from Yahoo Mail on Android
  
 From: Jesse Ward-Karet <jwk@tanium.com;
 To: Jim Resch <jim.resch@tanium.com;
 Cc: Kevin Chu <kevin.chu@tanium.com; Peter Lincroft 
 <peter@ansiblesoftware.com; Ben Hobbs <ben.hobbs@tanium.com;
 Subject: Re: Allegiant Air | Questions related to License Count
 Sent: Mon, Jul 28, 2014 6:29:40 PM
  
 There is a bug that is sort of tracking this issue: 
 https://bugs.tanium.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1751
 
 I believe the problem is basically that we use the system status count to display the license information (but not to enforce it!). There is an API call to get the official client count, and as far as I know it just returns the 30 day system status count without de-duplication or filtering. We either need to adjust that API to return a "better" count, or add a new one.
 
 I need Peter or Ben to comment on the exact logic that goes into the result of GetObject--client_count.
 
 Although I do think we should fix this, it's worth noting that the license warning is simply cosmetic. As long as they are under their licensed count for the previous 24 hour period the system will be fully functional even if the warning message says otherwise.
 
 Jesse
 
 On Jul 28, 2014, at 11:05 AM, Jim Resch <jim.resch@tanium.com wrote:
 
  Hi, Jesse,
   
  Based on Kevin’s suggestion, I’ll stop by to talk to you about the issue below directly, but wanted to forward this information in advance for your review.
   
  Allegiant Air has a license for 1,500 seats. 
   
  They have about 1,100 to 1,200 unique computers to manage—nearly all of the machines are physical with very little virtualization.  Because of the nature of their business, most computers are not powered off at the end of the day.
   
  When they login to the console, they see the following message:
   
  <image007.jpg
   
  We temporarily gave them a new license for 1700 seats while we look into their questions about the reported overage.  The error message is now replaced with a warning message:
   
  <image005.jpg
   
  The 1 day and 30 day screenshots from Allegiant are included earlier in this email message.
  ·        When we view the registered computers within the last 24 hours from the System Status tab, their console shows 1088 computers.
  ·        When we view the registered computers within the last 30 days, their console shows 1707 computers
   
  Ok, nothing unexpected so far since our licensing is based on unique computer registrations within the last 30 days.
   
  However, if we look more closely at the report for 30 days, we also see that 387 of those computers are reporting a version of 0.0.0.0.  In the 24 hour report, only 38 computers show a version of 0.0.0.0 
  ·      In all but one of the highlighted groups below, one entry shows the host name as the computer name while the other shows the domain name
  ·      In about half of the highlighted groups below, one entry shows the host name as the computer name while the other shows the domain name  as well as the IP address is different in the second entry.
  But should any of those differences really matter?  I thought the uniqueness of the computer was being tracked by the Computer ID.  So as long as the computer ID remains the same, the device consumes only one license regardless of host name, IP address, MAC Address changes, etc.  Is that not correct? 
  It seems as if a good number of the computers are consuming two 
  licenses—once for the computer name reporting a version number of 
  0.0.0.0 and then again for the domain name reporting a full 
  version number:  6.0.314.1190… If we take the 30 day registrations 
  (1707) and remove all but the last 24 hours  of computers 
  reporting a version of 0.0.0.0 (387-38), the number of clients is 
  well under their original license of 1,500:  1707 – (387 – 38)  = 
  1358 <image001.jpg  Best regards,
   
  Jim Resch
  Technical Account Manager
   
  Jim.Resch@Tanium.com | +1 (510) 919-8828
   
  Support:  http://www.tanium.com/resources/
   
  From: Kevin Chu [mailto:kevin.chu@tanium.com]
  Sent: Monday, July 28, 2014 10:00 AM
  To: Jim Resch
  Subject: Re: Allegiant Air | New Tanium license file to resolve 
  console warning message
   
  Hi Jim,
   
  We need Jesse's input here.  I'll be back in the office on Wednesday, but you can also check in with him directly -- your data is pretty darn clear.
   
  Kevin
   
  From: Antonio Rivas [mailto:Antonio.Rivas@allegiantair.com]
  Sent: Wednesday, July 23, 2014 11:03 AM
  To: Jim Resch
  Cc: Andrew White
  
  Subject: RE: Allegiant Air | New Tanium license file to resolve 
  console warning message Hi Jim, Here you go  Show system that have 
  reported in the last 1 day:
  <image002.jpg
   Show system that have reported in the last 30 days:
  <image003.jpg
   Thanks
   -Antonio
 
 To: Jim Resch
  Cc: Todd Brydon; Kevin Chu
  Subject: RE: Allegiant Air | New Tanium license file to resolve 
  console warning message  I applied the new license, but I am still seeing this:
  <image005.jpg
  Which is odd since we don’t have that many agents, I don’t 
  understand why this shows so many seats used -Antonio
   From: Jim Resch [mailto:jim.resch@tanium.com]
  Sent: Tuesday, July 22, 2014 6:59 PM
  To: Antonio Rivas
  Cc: Todd Brydon; Kevin Chu
  Subject: Allegiant Air | New Tanium license file to resolve 
  console warning message  Hi, Antonio,  Attached is the updated 
  license I requested to eliminate the warning message you are seeing on the Tanium Console.
   Complete these steps to activate the new license:
      • Rename the existing license file in the Tanium Server’s installation folder from  \Program Files\Tanium\Tanium Server\tanium.license to tanium.license.Today’sDate
      • Save the attached file, tanium.license,  to the Tanium Server’s installation folder
      • Restart the Tanium Server service  Let me know if you have 
  any questions; otherwise, please confirm that you have received the file and that the new license has been activated.
  Best regards,
  Jim Resch
  Technical Account Manager
  Jim.Resch@Tanium.com | +1 (510) 919-8828
  Support:  http://www.tanium.com/resources/

fields.description:
During the investigation of 
https://jira.corp.tanium.com/browse/INTERACT-1194

It was found that one of the files that should never be cached, was being cached.

We do not have any recreate steps for this:  The server started caching the file, and because it was cached, login to the server was not possible.  Restarting the server solved the problem.

It was not seen until after the restart and the bug was analyzed that the only cause was that the /nocache/ file was being cached.  

This bug is being opened to track if this ever happens again, and to link any other problems that might be caused by a similarly "cached, but shouldn't be" issues
fields.summary: Server caching files in /nocache/*, when they should not be

fields.description:
The current settings (DownloadBytesPerSecondLimit, sensor_bytes_per_second_limit , ConcurrentPackageFileDownloadsLimit) does not provide the desired result as we cannot control/restrict bandwidth on the subnet/network/client level.  We propose that we extend the current Download and Sensor Sync settings to be network/subnet aware/specific.  Example Below:

BandwidthControl.txt
CIDR Network		DownloadBytesPerSecondLimit	sensor_bytes_per_second_limit
192.168.10.0/24	        10000000			50000
192.168.11.0/24	        25000000			25000	
10.10.10.0/24		30000000			50000


While this is a manual configuration and is not the ideal end-state, it closes a big gap in our current package distribution and bandwidth control offering.  This certainly won’t fix all bandwidth woes but it will go a long way in assisting the TAM in certain bandwidth constrained scenarios where there is no other currently available solution (QoS).  This setting would need to be available at the server and zone server level and would apply to Download and Sensor Sync traffic only.

Depending on complexity, this should be considered for backport to 6.5 and 6.2
fields.summary: Limiting Bandwidth to network segments a'la IsolatedSubnets

fields.description:
Right now we don't set any cache-control headers on the console content. That's probably good for most content, as we don't have a version distinguisher in the URL at this point. However, we do have a version number in Console.swf, so we could safely tell the client to cache it. That would avoid 3MB on every page view.

Can we add this to the headers only for the swf?

cache-control: max-age=31536000

That should make it cached for 365 days....
fields.summary: We should set a cache-control header when serving up Console.swf, since the version is in the name.

fields.description:
Sony of America has reported a vulnerability they they find severe. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

There are known flaws in the SSLv2 protocol. A man-in-the-middle attacker can 
force the communication to a less secure level and then attempt to break the 
weak encryption. The attacker can also truncate encrypted messages.

These flaws have been fixed in SSLv3 (or TLSv1). Most servers (including all 
popular Web servers, mail servers, etc.) and clients (including Web-clients 
like IE, Netscape Navigator and Mozilla and mail clients) support both SSLv2 
and SSLv3. However, SSLv2 is enabled by default for backward compatibility.

Disable SSLv2.

Typically, for Apache/mod_ssl, httpd.conf or ssl.conf should have the following 
lines:
SSLProtocol -ALL +SSLv3 +TLSv1
SSLCipherSuite ALL:!aNULL:!ADH:!eNULL:!LOW:!EXP:RC4+RSA:+HIGH:+MEDIUM

For Apache/apache_ssl, httpd.conf or ssl.conf should have the following line:
SSLNoV2
fields.summary: Disable SSLv2 in the SOAP Server...

fields.description:
The console side of the value system implementation is in place (but hidden).

There are two new tables and a new group type:

groups_computer_specs (group_id, computer_spec_id)

computer_specs (id, computer_name default null, ip_address default null, enabled_flag)

The groups that use this are type 4. I had to use the existing groups table because I want these groups to be usable anywhere other named groups can be used for filtering, so they have an associated groups_boolean_bits row as well as a filter spec that corresponds to 'Manual Group Membership is <group_id>'.

As discussed, if a change to the group definition is detected, any current or former members of the groups will get a reset message upon normal registration. On initial registration, clients will retrieve their group definitions and store them in the value system. 

I will file another bug for the content side of this. Peter, it will need comments from you concerning how to inspect the registry to determine group membership.

Would be cool if in the "users" and "computer groups" tabs you could actually query Active Directory for existing user groups or computer groups.  For users, it could ask for what role you want to set and it would automatically create that batch of users.  For computer groups, we could auto-generate the filter since it would just be: "AD Computer Group contains OU=GROUP,CN=TANIUM,CN=US" or something.

If we end up doing this I can handle the AD/PHP side if you'd like.  Just let me know.
